Name: Oxathiapiprolin
Description: 1-(4-{4-[5-(2,6-difluorophenyl)-4,5-dihydro-1,2-oxazol-3-yl]-1,3-thiazol-2-yl}piperidin-1-yl)-2-[5-methyl-3-(trifluoromethyl)-1H-pyrazol-1-yl]ethanone is an N-acylpiperidine that is N-acetyl 4-(1,3-thiazol-2-yl)piperidine in which the thiazole ring is substituted at position 4 by a 5-(2,6-difluorophenyl)-4,5-dihydro-1,2-oxazol-3-yl group and in which one of the hydrogens of the acetyl group is replaced by a 5-methyl-3-(trifluoromethyl)-1H-pyrazol-1-yl group. It is a N-acylpiperidine, a member of 1,3-thiazoles, a member of pyrazoles, an organofluorine compound, an isoxazoline and a tertiary carboxamide.

plant_translocations.content: Oxathiapiprolin is a recently registered fungicide in the United States that has shown significant efficacy against Phytophthora blight on bell pepper. However, it was previously unknown whether oxathiapiprolin translocates systemically in bell pepper plants after application. Experiments were conducted to determine the uptake of oxathiapiprolin by pepper plants and its movement within the plant system. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was used to quantify oxathiapiprolin in plant tissues, with a recovery percentage ranging from 87.0% to 119.3%. When applied to the roots of bell pepper plants grown in hydroponics, oxathiapiprolin was detected in the roots within 4 hours and in the cotyledon, first true leaf, and second true leaf within 8 hours. In greenhouse studies with potted bell pepper plants, oxathiapiprolin was detectable in the roots within 3 days and in the stem and first true leaf within 6 days when applied at 100 μg/g. When applied at 400 μg/g, it was detected in the root, stem, first true leaf, and top new leaf. These findings provide valuable information for designing effective fungicide application strategies for managing Phytophthora blight in bell pepper.
plant_translocations.reference: Qu, T., Grey, T. L., Csinos, A. S., & Ji, P. (2016). Translocation of oxathiapiprolin in bell pepper plants and systemic protection of plants against Phytophthora blight. Plant Disease, 100(9), 1931-1936.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Seedlings grown from seed in 8.5 cm pots with commercial potting mix under greenhouse conditions until 6-7 leaf stage. For translocation study, hydroponically grown plants used.
method.Chemical Preparation: Oxathiapiprolin (99% purity) dissolved in 1% formic acid in acetonitrile at various concentrations (1.5-500 μg/ml) for HPLC calibration. For plant treatments - 12 μg/ml used for spiking tissues, 100 μg/ml used for root application in hydroculture.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Roots of hydroponically grown plants placed in 125 ml of 100 μg/ml solution. Controls in water only.
method.Other Information: Randomized complete block with 5 reps. Sampled roots, stem, cotyledons, 1st, 2nd and top leaves at 0-144 h intervals. Extracts kept at 4°C, analyzed within 3 days.

plant_translocations.content: The study investigated the uptake, translocation, and subcellular distribution of oxathiapiprolin and famoxadone in tomato plants using hydroponic experiments. The results showed that both fungicides mainly accumulated in the tomato roots with limited translocation to the upper parts of the plant. Root absorption and inhibitor studies indicated the dominance of apoplastic and symplastic pathways in the uptake of oxathiapiprolin and famoxadone by the tomato roots, respectively. The uptake process for both fungicides followed passive and aquaporin-dependent transport mechanisms. In terms of storage, insoluble cell components such as cell organelles and walls were the dominant compartments for both fungicides. In the protoplast, oxathiapiprolin had a higher proportion in the soluble fraction compared to famoxadone. Overall, the study provides a detailed understanding of the transfer of oxathiapiprolin and famoxadone from the environment to tomato plants, which can be useful for predicting their uptake and distribution.
plant_translocations.reference: Feng, X., Liu, G., Wang, X., An, K., Guo, Y., Liu, Y., & Dong, J. (2022). Uptake, translocation, and subcellular distribution of oxathiapiprolin and famoxadone in tomato plants (Lycopersicon esculentum Miller). Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, 70(39), 12310-12319.

method.Plant Growth Condition: Then transferred to nutrient solution (composition given in Table S1, pH 6.5) and grown for 3 more weeks, renewing solution every 2 days. Uniform seedlings with 12±1 cm roots, 30±1 cm shoots selected and transplanted into PVC boxes with 5 L nutrient solution per box (15 seedlings/box) for exposure experiments.
method.Chemical Preparation: Oxathiapiprolin and famoxadone prepared in nutrient solutions at 0, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, 10 mg/L concentrations.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 2 g fresh/dead roots incubated in 10 mL 0.01 M CaCl2 with 100 mg/L NaN3 and fungicides at 0.5-10 mg/L for 24 h.
method.Other Information: 3 replicates per concentration. Roots/shoots separated, weighed, roots homogenized to quantify fungicide.
